metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data of Early Cretaceous Xiabie Co granite and microgranular enclaves in northern Niyma County, Tibet
metadata.description: Data contain the whole-rock major, trace elements, Sr Nd isotopes, zircon U-Pb and Hf-O isotopic data, and major oxides contents of the major rock-forming minerals of host granites and microgranular enclaves collected from the Nyima area, central Tibet.  The whole-rock major element data are obtained by X-ray fluorescence spectrometry, the trace element data are obtained by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, the Sr and Nd isotope data are obtained by multi collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and the major element chemical data of minerals are obtained by electron probe microanalyzer, Zircon U-Pb and Hf isotopic data were obtained by laser ablation combined with inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and zircon O isotopic data were analyzed by secondary ion mass spectrometry. These data were used for further explore the petrogenesis of these granites and hosed enclaves.
metadata.instructions: All data are stored in Excel file. The file name "ZirocnUPb. XLS" represents zircon U-Pb isotope data. The file name "zircon HfO. XLS" represents zircon Hf and oxygen isotope data. The file name "WRMajorTrace. XLS" represents the whole rock major and trace geochemical data. The file name "WRSrNd. XLS" represents the whole rock Sr and Nd isotopic data. The name of the file is "MineralMajor. XLS", which represents the data of mineral major elements.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the geochemical data collected from granites and dark fine-grained enclaves in the northern Nima County?
Feature Specification.Answer: whole-rock major and trace elements, Sr-Nd isotopes, zircon U-Pb and Hf-O isotopes, mineral major element chemistry

Definition.Question: What is the role of Sr-Nd isotopic data in understanding the genesis of granites and dark fine-grained enclaves?
Definition.Answer: Sr-Nd isotopic data is used to analyze the isotopic composition of rocks, which helps in understanding the source and history of the granites and dark fine-grained enclaves. It provides insights into the origin and evolution of these geological formations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences on geological understanding when utilizing advanced techniques like X-ray fluorescence, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and laser ablation for data collection in geochemical studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of advanced techniques such as X-ray fluorescence, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and laser ablation in geochemical studies can result in a comprehensive understanding of geological formations. These methods enable precise measurement of major and trace elements, as well as isotopic compositions, which can reveal the origins and evolutionary history of rock formations, including granites and dark fine-grained enclaves. Additionally, the integration of zircon U-Pb dating and Hf-O isotopic analysis provides insights into the timing and source characteristics of magmatic events, thus enhancing geological models and interpretations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the methods used to obtain comprehensive geochemical data, including major and trace elements, and isotopic compositions from granitic and mafic enclaves in the early Cretaceous period in northern Nyima County, Tibet?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The geochemical data collection involves several techniques: major element data is obtained through X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy, trace element data is acquired using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, Sr-Nd isotopic data is tested using multi-receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, mineral major element chemical data is measured by electron probe analysis, zircon U-Pb and Hf isotopic data are obtained by laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and zircon O isotopic data is analyzed using secondary ion mass spectrometry.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the collection and analysis of detailed geochemical data from granites and mafic enclaves in geological studies?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy for major element data, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for trace element data, multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for Sr-Nd isotopic data, electron probe microanalysis for mineral chemistry, laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for zircon U-Pb and Hf isotopic data, and secondary ion mass spectrometry for zircon O isotopic data enable the collection and analysis of detailed geochemical data.
